Data Distribution Valuation

Xinyi Xu
Department of Computer Science
National University of Singapore
xinyi.xu@u.nus.edu
Majority of work done when visiting CMU.    Shuaiqi Wang

shuaiqiw@andrew.cmu.edu
   Chuan-Sheng Foo

   Giulia Fanti
Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
Carnegie Mellon University
gfanti@andrew.cmu.edu
Abstract

Data valuation is a class of techniques for quantitatively assessing the value of data for applications like pricing in data marketplaces. Existing data valuation methods define a value for a discrete dataset. However, in many use cases, users are interested in not only the value of the dataset, but that of the distribution from which the dataset was sampled. For example, consider a buyer trying to evaluate whether to purchase data from different vendors. The buyer may observe (and compare) only a small preview sample from each vendor, to decide which vendor’s data distribution is most useful to the buyer and purchase. The core question is how should we compare the values of data distributions from their samples? Under a Huber characterization of the data heterogeneity across vendors, we propose a maximum mean discrepancy (MMD)-based valuation method which enables theoretically principled and actionable policies for comparing data distributions from samples. We empirically demonstrate that our method is sample-efficient and effective in identifying valuable data distributions against several existing baselines, on multiple real-world datasets (e.g., network intrusion detection, credit card fraud detection) and downstream applications (classification, regression).

1 Introduction

Data valuation is a widely-studied practice of quantifying the value of data [57]. Today, data valuation methods define a value for a discrete dataset D𝐷Ditalic_D, i.e., a fixed set of samples [24, 32]. However, many emerging use cases require a data user to evaluate the quality of not just a dataset, but the distribution from which the data was sampled. For example, data vendors in markets like Datarade and Snowflake, financial data streams [46, 52], information security data [22]) offer a preview in the form of a sample dataset to prospective buyers [4, 11]. Similarly, enterprises selling access to generative models may offer a limited preview of the output distributions to prospective buyers [53]. Buyers use these sample datasets to decide whether to pay for a full dataset or data stream—i.e., access to the data distribution. Concretely, the buyers would compare between different data distributions (via their respective sample datasets) to determine and select the more valuable one.

In such applications, existing dataset valuation metrics are missing two components: (1) They do not formalize the value of the underlying sampling distribution, (2) nor do they provide a theoretically principled and actionable policy for comparing different sampling distributions based on the sample datasets. For example, most existing data valuation techniques are designed only to value a dataset [57]. To our knowledge, there are no methods designed to value an underlying distribution.

To model this problem, we consider a data buyer who wishes to evaluate n𝑛nitalic_n data vendors, each with their own dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT drawn i.i.d. from distribution Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ]. The vendors’ distributions are heterogeneous, i.e., the Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s can differ across vendors. Such distributional heterogeneity can arise from natural variations in data [12] or adversarial data corruption [27, 64]. The buyer’s goal is to select the vendor whose data distribution is closest in some sense (to be defined) to a reference distribution P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is fixed but unknown. Our goal is to provide both a precise definition for the value of the vendor distribution Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as well as a corresponding valuation for the sample dataset Di∼Pisimilar-tosubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖D_{i}\sim P_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In particular, we want precise conditions under which, given two datasets Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Djsubscript𝐷𝑗D_{j}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT drawn from distributions Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pjsubscript𝑃𝑗P_{j}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, we can conclude that Pi>Pj+εΥsubscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑃𝑗subscript𝜀ΥP_{i}>P_{j}+\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Υ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some user-specified εΥ>0subscript𝜀Υ0\varepsilon_{\Upsilon}>0italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Υ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 with fixed probability. While this problem is straightforward when different vendors have the same underlying distribution, the main challenge is accounting for the heterogeneity in the data.

We thus identify three technical and modeling challenges: (i) What is a suitable heterogeneity model that captures realistic data patterns, while also admitting theoretical analysis? (ii) How should one define the value of a distribution under a given heterogeneity model? (iii) Many existing data valuation methods use a reference P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, either explicitly [24, 33, 55] or implicitly [1, 14]. However, there are practical difficulties: (1) different data vendors may disagree on the choice of reference [69], (2) such a reference may not be available a priori [14, 56], or (3) dishonest vendors may try to overfit to the reference [2]. To address this, some works consider alternatives (to P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) based on the vendors’ distributions Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s such as their union [59] or a certain combination [65], but without theoretical analysis or justifications for their specific choices. So what is a practical alternative, and how can we theoretically justify it?

To address these challenges, we make three key choices.

(a) Heterogeneity model. We assume that each vendor’s data distribution Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Huber model [30], which is a mixture model of the unknown distribution P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and an arbitrary outlier distribution Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. While the Huber model does not capture all kinds of statistical heterogeneity, mixture models both are a reasonable model for data heterogeneity in practice [9, 54] and have deeper roots in robust statistics [20, 40]. More importantly, the Huber model enables a direct and precise characterization of the effect of heterogeneity on the value of data (under our design choices (b) and (c) below), which has not been considered in prior works [1, 14, 65].

(b) Value of a sampling distribution. We use the negative maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) [26] between a reference distribution P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and P𝑃Pitalic_P as the value of the sampling distribution P𝑃Pitalic_P. Then, we leverage a (uniformly converging) MMD estimator [26] to derive actionable policies for comparing sampling distributions with theoretical guarantees. In other words, a buyer can compare (the values of) sampling distributions Pi,Pi′subscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑃superscript𝑖′P_{i},P_{i^{\prime}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (from vendors i,i′𝑖superscript𝑖′i,i^{\prime}italic_i , italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) based on the respective samples Di,Di′subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐷superscript𝑖′D_{i},D_{i^{\prime}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to determine which is more valuable, and by how much.

(c) Choice of reference data distribution and dataset. Unlike in prior works (e.g., [24, 66]), we do not specify a reference distribution outright. Instead, we consider a class of convex mixtures of vendor distributions as the reference. We first derive error guarantees and an actionable comparison policy for using general convex mixture of the vendors’ distributions as the reference. We then propose to use the special case of a uniform mixture, justified by a game-theoretic argument, stating that the uniform strategy is worst-case optimal in a two-player zero-sum game.

These design choices are not isolated answers to each technical challenge, but collectively address these challenges (e.g., the analytic properties of both Huber and MMD are needed to compare distributions effectively). Our specific contributions are summarized as follows:

  • ∙∙\bullet∙

    We formulate the problem of data distribution valuation in data markets and study an MMD-based method for data distribution valuation. Under a Huber model of data heterogeneity, we show that this data valuation metric admits actionable, theoretically-grounded policies for comparing sampling distributions from samples.

  • ∙∙\bullet∙

    We derive an error guarantee (2) and comparison policy (Theorem 1) for a general convex mixture Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a reference (in place of P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), thus relaxing the common assumption of knowing P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We then identify the uniform mixture as a game-theoretic special case for Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • ∙∙\bullet∙

    We demonstrate on real-world classification (e.g., network intrusion detection) and regression (e.g., income prediction) tasks that our method is sample-efficient, and effective in identifying the most valuable sampling distributions against existing baselines. For example, on classification tasks, we observed that an MMD-based valuation method outperformed four leading valuation metrics on 3 out of 4 classification settings (Table 2).

2 Related Work

Existing dataset valuation methods fall roughly in 2222 categories: those that assume a given reference dataset, and those that do not. We defer additional discussion to App. B due to space constraints.

With a given reference. Several existing methods require a given reference in the form of a validation set (e.g., [24, 39]) or a baseline dataset [2]. Data Shapley [24], Beta Shapley [39] and Data Banzhaf [43, 62] utilize the validation accuracy of a trained model as the value of the training data. Class-wise Shapley [55] evaluates the effects of a dataset on the in-class and out-of-class validation accuracies. Both LAVA [33] and DAVINZ [66] use a proxy for the validation performance of the training data as their value, instead of the actual validation performance, to be independent of the choice of downstream task ML model [33] or to remove the need for model training [66]. Differently, [2] assume that the buyer provides a baseline dataset as the reference to calculate a relevance score used to evaluate the vendor’s data. Therefore, these methods cannot be applied without such a given reference, which can be difficult to obtain in practice [14, 56]. In contrast, our method can be applied without a given reference, by carefully constructing a reference (Sec. 4.2).

Without a given reference. To relax the assumption of a given reference, [14, 59, 65] construct a reference from the data from all vendors. While the settings of [14, 59, 65] can include heterogeneity in the vendors’ data, they do not explicitly formalize it and thus cannot precisely analyze its effects on data valuation. In contrast, our method, via the careful design choices of the Huber model (for heterogeneity) and MMD (for valuation), uniquely offers a precise analysis on the effect of heterogeneity on the value of data (Eq. 2). Furthermore, these methods did not provide theoretical guarantees on the error arising from using their constructed reference in place of the ground truth (i.e., P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). In contrast, by exploiting 1 in the setting of multiple vendors and the MMD-based valuation (Eq. 1), we provide such theoretical guarantees (e.g., 2). In a different approach to relax the assumption of a given reference, [56, 69] remove the dependence on a reference; as a result they can produce counter-intuitive data values under heterogeneous data (experiments in Sec. 5). The closest related work to ours is [59], which adopts the MMD2 as a valuation metric, primarily for computational reasons. However, this work does not consider data distribution valuation, nor does it describe how to compare (the values of) distributions, let alone with theoretical guarantees. This comparison (with MMD2) is expanded in Sec. B.2.

Table 1 provides a comparison between our choice (MMD) and three others: the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence [1, 65], the Wasserstein distance (WD) [33], and squared MMD (MMD2) [59].

3 Model, Problem Statement and MMD

We consider a set of data vendors i∈N≔{1,…,n}𝑖𝑁≔1…𝑛i\in N\coloneqq\{1,\ldots,n\}italic_i ∈ italic_N ≔ { 1 , … , italic_n }, each with a sample dataset Di≔{zi,1,…,zi,mi}≔subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑧𝑖1…subscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖D_{i}\coloneqq\{z_{i,1},\ldots,z_{i,m_{i}}\}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ { italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of size misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where zi,jsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑗z_{i,j}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is sampled i.i.d. from the distribution Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [10]. Slightly abusing notations, we write Di∼Pisimilar-tosubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖D_{i}\sim P_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We assume the existence of an unknown ground truth distribution P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, called the test distribution [24, 32], true data distribution [1] or the task distribution [2].

Huber model. We assume that each sampling distribution Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows a Huber model [30], defined as follows: Pi=(1−εi)⁢P∗+εi⁢Qisubscript𝑃𝑖1subscript𝜀𝑖superscript𝑃subscript𝜀𝑖subscript𝑄𝑖P_{i}=(1-\varepsilon_{i})P^{*}+\varepsilon_{i}Q_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where εi∈[0,1)subscript𝜀𝑖01\varepsilon_{i}\in[0,1)italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , 1 ) and Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a distribution that captures the heterogeneity of vendor i𝑖iitalic_i [27]. For notational simplicity, we omit the subscript i𝑖iitalic_i and write D,P𝐷𝑃D,Pitalic_D , italic_P instead of Di,Pisubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖D_{i},P_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, when it is clear. We adopt the Huber model because (i) it is sufficiently general to model various sources of heterogeneity [12, 13]; (ii) Huber models are “closed” under mixtures (i.e., a mixture of Hubers is a Huber model), so we can define a mixture over data vendors’ distributions:

Problem statement. Given two datasets D∼Psimilar-to𝐷𝑃D\sim Pitalic_D ∼ italic_P and D′∼P′similar-tosuperscript𝐷′superscript𝑃′D^{\prime}\sim P^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we seek a distribution valuation function Υ⁢(⋅)Υ⋅\Upsilon(\cdot)roman_Υ ( ⋅ ) and a dataset valuation function ν⁢(⋅)𝜈⋅\nu(\cdot)italic_ν ( ⋅ ) which enable a set of conditions under which to conclude that Υ⁢(P)>Υ⁢(P′)Υ𝑃Υsuperscript𝑃′\Upsilon(P)>\Upsilon(P^{\prime})roman_Υ ( italic_P ) > roman_Υ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), given only ν⁢(D)𝜈𝐷\nu(D)italic_ν ( italic_D ) and ν⁢(D′)𝜈superscript𝐷′\nu(D^{\prime})italic_ν ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Moreover, we seek a practical implementation of ΥΥ\Upsilonroman_Υ that does not require access to the ground truth distribution P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as reference or any prior knowledge about the vendors (except each Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Huber).

Existing methods cannot be easily applied to solve this problem. First, existing methods (e.g., [24, 32] do not define ΥΥ\Upsilonroman_Υ; hence, they cannot analyze the conditions under which Υ⁢(P)>Υ⁢(P′)Υ𝑃Υsuperscript𝑃′\Upsilon(P)>\Upsilon(P^{\prime})roman_Υ ( italic_P ) > roman_Υ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). In App. C, we elaborate why a dataset valuation ν𝜈\nuitalic_ν cannot be easily extended to a data distribution valuation ΥΥ\Upsilonroman_Υ and also highlight the theoretical appeal of directly considering ΥΥ\Upsilonroman_Υ instead. Additionally, methods that explicitly require access to the reference distribution via D∗∼P∗similar-tosuperscript𝐷superscript𝑃D^{*}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (e.g., [39, 55, 66]) cannot be applied here. For other methods, additional non-trivial assumptions (e.g., [14, Assumption 3.2], [65, Assumption 3.1]) are required; we elaborate on these in Sec. B.1.

3.1 Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD)

The MMD is an integral probability metric proposed to test if two distributions are the same.

4 MMD-based Data Distribution Valuation

A distribution valuation function should intuitively reward distributions P𝑃Pitalic_P that are “closer" to the reference distribution P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; accordingly, it should assign greater reward to datasets D∼Psimilar-to𝐷𝑃D\sim Pitalic_D ∼ italic_P that are drawn from distributions that are closer to P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We study the following data distribution valuation:

Υ⁢(P)≔−d⁢(P,P∗),ν⁢(D)≔−d^⁢(D,D∗).formulae-sequence≔Υ𝑃𝑑𝑃superscript𝑃≔𝜈𝐷^𝑑𝐷superscript𝐷\Upsilon(P)\coloneqq-d(P,P^{*})\ ,\quad\nu(D)\coloneqq-\hat{d}(D,D^{*})\ .roman_Υ ( italic_P ) ≔ - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_ν ( italic_D ) ≔ - over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (1)

To interpret, the value Υ⁢(P)Υ𝑃\Upsilon(P)roman_Υ ( italic_P ) of a vendor’s sampling distribution P𝑃Pitalic_P is defined as the negated MMD between P𝑃Pitalic_P and P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, while the value ν⁢(D)𝜈𝐷\nu(D)italic_ν ( italic_D ) of its sample dataset D𝐷Ditalic_D is defined as the negated MMD estimate between D𝐷Ditalic_D and the reference dataset D∗superscript𝐷D^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

On the choice of MMD. We summarize a comparison with three alternatives (i.e., KL-divergence (KL), Wasserstein Distance (WD), and MMD2) in Table 1 to highlight the suitability of MMD for data distribution valuation. Despite its wide adoption, KL is difficult to estimate, and the available estimator only has asymptotic convergence guarantees [63] (rather than a finite-sample result), which can be arbitrarily slow. Its implementation also suffers from the curse of dimensionality [58, 63]. In addition, KL does not satisfy the triangle inequality, which our proof technique uses in 2. WD, also known as the optimal transport (OT) distance [34], suffers from the curse of dimensionality, as seen in the complexity results [23] in Table 1, and is more computationally costly to evaluate than MMD. MMD2, though shares similar complexity results to MMD, does not satisfy desirable analytic properties, such as the triangle inequality or the property with Huber model. This comparison over divergences is expanded in Sec. B.2.

MMD is both practically and theoretically appealing for data distribution valuation. Practically, MMD has lower sample and computational complexities in the dimension of the data, which is important because the real-world datasets can be complex and have a high dimension. Specifically, we leverage the uniform convergence (with sample complexity as in Table 1) of an MMD estimator to derive an actionable policy for comparing two distributions (i.e., 1, Theorem 1). Theoretically, MMD satisfies the triangle inequality, making it amenable to theoretical analysis, such as the derivation of our error guarantee (i.e., 2). Moreover, MMD pairs well with the Huber model in providing a precise characterization of the effect of heterogeneity on the value of data. In contrast, existing valuation works have not established a formal analysis on the heterogeneity (w.r.t. a specific choice for heterogeneity) on the value of data, elaborated in Sec. B.3.

Effect of heterogeneity on data valuation. Intuitively, the quality of a Huber distribution P𝑃Pitalic_P depends on both the size of the outlier component ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε and the statistical difference d⁢(P∗,Q)𝑑superscript𝑃𝑄d(P^{*},Q)italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ) between Q𝑄Qitalic_Q and P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A larger ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε and/or a larger d⁢(P∗,Q)𝑑superscript𝑃𝑄d(P^{*},Q)italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ) decreases the value Υ⁢(P)Υ𝑃\Upsilon(P)roman_Υ ( italic_P ). Our choice of MMD makes this intuition precise and interpretable: By Lemma 2, for P=(1−ε)⁢P∗+ε⁢Q𝑃1𝜀superscript𝑃𝜀𝑄P=(1-\varepsilon)P^{*}+\varepsilon Qitalic_P = ( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_ε italic_Q,

Υ⁢(P)=−ε⁢d⁢(P∗,Q).Υ𝑃𝜀𝑑superscript𝑃𝑄\Upsilon(P)=-\varepsilon d(P^{*},Q)\ .roman_Υ ( italic_P ) = - italic_ε italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ) . (2)

Eq. 2 shows that for a fixed ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε, P𝑃Pitalic_P’s value decreases linearly w.r.t. d⁢(P∗,Q)𝑑superscript𝑃𝑄d(P^{*},Q)italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ); similarly, for a fixed d⁢(P∗,Q)𝑑superscript𝑃𝑄d(P^{*},Q)italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Q ), P𝑃Pitalic_P’s value decreases linearly w.r.t. ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε. Importantly, Eq. 2 enables subsequent results and a theoretically justified choice for the reference (e.g., Lemma 4 to derive Theorem 1 in Sec. 4.2).

4.2 Approximating the Reference Distribution

Previously we assumed P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT could be accessed as the reference. We now relax this assumption by replacing P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with a mixture distribution Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over all the vendors’ distributions, as defined in 1. We first prove an error guarantee to generalize 1 when using Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT instead of P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We then use a game-theoretic formulation to motivate the choice of the uniform mixture, PUsubscript𝑃UP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Importantly, this result implies that using Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (to replace P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) retains the previous analysis and interpretation: a buyer’s requirement via the decision margin can be satisfied by the vendors providing (sufficiently) large sample datasets, which is empirically investigated in a comparison against existing valuation methods (Sec. 5). We highlight that Theorem 1 exploits the closed property of Huber models (via 1), the triangle inequality of MMD (via 2) and the uniform convergence of the MMD estimator. Hence, the modeling and design choices of Huber and MMD are both necessary.

4.2.1 A Game-theoretic Choice of Mixture

The above results hold for general mixture distributions Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, begging the question: Which mixture should one use (i.e., what ω𝜔\omegaitalic_ω)? A game-theoretic formulation reveals that the uniform strategy is worst-case optimal, so we propose to use the uniform mixture PUsubscript𝑃UP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the special case of Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Consider the following two-player zero-sum game. A payoff matrix ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R consists of n𝑛nitalic_n rows, one corresponding to each vendor index, and n!𝑛n!italic_n ! columns, one corresponding to each permutation over the vendor indices. The row player (i.e., the agent conducting the data valuation) picks a vendor index r∈N𝑟𝑁r\in Nitalic_r ∈ italic_N. The column player (hypothetical adversary) then adversarially chooses a permutation πcsubscript𝜋𝑐\pi_{c}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the indices in N𝑁Nitalic_N. Hence, the action space for the row player is N𝑁Nitalic_N and that for the column player is all possible permutations of {1,2⁢…,n}12…𝑛\{1,2\ldots,n\}{ 1 , 2 … , italic_n }.444W.l.o.g. assume a fixed ordering of all n!𝑛n!italic_n ! permutations. The column player represents the fact that the row player lacks prior knowledge about vendors: hence it selects an index r𝑟ritalic_r in any possible arbitrary permutation πcsubscript𝜋𝑐\pi_{c}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, for a pair of actions (r,πc)𝑟subscript𝜋𝑐(r,\pi_{c})( italic_r , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the quality of the distribution Pπc⁢[r]subscript𝑃subscript𝜋𝑐delimited-[]𝑟P_{\pi_{c}[r]}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the row player’s payoff ℛr,c≔−d⁢(P∗,Pπc⁢[r])≔subscriptℛ𝑟𝑐𝑑superscript𝑃subscript𝑃subscript𝜋𝑐delimited-[]𝑟\mathcal{R}_{r,c}\coloneqq-d(P^{*},P_{\pi_{c}[r]})caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ - italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), defined as the negated MMD between Pπc⁢[r]subscript𝑃subscript𝜋𝑐delimited-[]𝑟P_{\pi_{c}[r]}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the optimal distribution P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., a lower MMD means a higher payoff), specifying the following optimization:

maxr⁡minc⁡ℛr,csubscript𝑟subscript𝑐subscriptℛ𝑟𝑐\textstyle\max_{r}\min_{c}\mathcal{R}_{r,c}roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r , italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (4)

where ℛ∈ℝn×(n!)ℛsuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑛\mathcal{R}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times(n!)}caligraphic_R ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × ( italic_n ! ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the payoff matrix and max\maxroman_max (min\minroman_min) denotes the row (column) player’s action. A strategy srow∈△⁢(n−1)subscript𝑠row△𝑛1s_{\text{row}}\in\triangle(n-1)italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT row end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ △ ( italic_n - 1 ) (as an n𝑛nitalic_n-dimensional probability vector) specifies the probability with which the row player picks a data vendor (at a position).

While efficient linear program solvers to Eq. 4 are available for explicitly specified ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R, in our setting, ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R is not explicitly specified due not knowing P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Fortunately, we show that the uniform strategy is optimal without knowing ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R explicitly:

Proposition 3.

The optimal solution for the row player to Eq. 4 is srow∗=[1n,1n,…,1n].subscriptsuperscript𝑠row1𝑛1𝑛…1𝑛s^{*}_{\text{row}}=[\frac{1}{n},\frac{1}{n},\ldots,\frac{1}{n}]\ .italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT row end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG , … , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ] .

(Proof in App. A) Intuitively, a uniform strategy over the vendors cannot be exploited by the column player, and is thus worst-case optimal. We highlight that while uniform strategy being worst-case optimal may seem intuitive, the mathematical properties and derivations needed are less straightforward. In particular, the proof depends on the “closed” property of Huber (i.e., 1) and the “linearity” of MMD applied to Huber (i.e., Eq. 2) to exploit the strong duality of a linear program. We also discuss alternative formulations to Eq. 4 in App. A.

Then, we adopt the uniform mixture PUsubscript𝑃UP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the special case of Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Eq. 3:

Υ^⁢(P)=−d⁢(P,PU),ν^⁢(D)≔−d^⁢(D,DU).formulae-sequence^Υ𝑃𝑑𝑃subscript𝑃U≔^𝜈𝐷^𝑑𝐷subscript𝐷U\hat{\Upsilon}(P)=-d(P,P_{\text{U}})\ ,\quad\hat{\nu}(D)\coloneqq-\hat{d}(D,D_% {\text{U}})\ .over^ start_ARG roman_Υ end_ARG ( italic_P ) = - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , over^ start_ARG italic_ν end_ARG ( italic_D ) ≔ - over^ start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ( italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (5)

2 and Theorem 1 are applied directly in App. A. The uniform mixture PUsubscript𝑃UP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is inspired from the solutions to Eq. 4, which is a game based on not having prior knowledge about the vendors. In this setting of no ground truth and no prior knowledge about the vendors, one might wonder if/how we can derive a lower bound of error to crystalize the difficulty of the problem (our 2 gives an upper bound of error for general Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Corollary 1 is for PUsubscript𝑃UP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). We expand this in App. C, making references to robust statistics and mechanism design.

5 Empirical Results

We first compare the sample efficiency of several baselines, and then investigate the effectiveness of our method in ranking n𝑛nitalic_n data distributions. Additional information on experimental settings is in App. C and additional results under non-Huber settings, and on scalability are in App. D. Our code is available at https://github.com/XinyiYS/Data_Distribution_Valuation.

Baselines. To accommodate the existing methods which explicitly require a validation set (Sec. 2), we perform some experiments using a validation set Dval∼P∗similar-tosubscript𝐷valsuperscript𝑃D_{\text{val}}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This assumption is made only for empirical comparison, and subsequently relaxed. The baselines that explicitly require Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are class-wise Shapley (CS) [55, Eq. (3)], LAVA [33] and DAVINZ [66, Eq. (3)]; the baselines that do not require Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are information-gain value (IG) [56, Eq. (1)], volume value (VV) [69, Eq. (2)] and MMD2 [59, Eq. (1)], which implements a biased estimator of MMD2. For each baseline, we adopt their official implementation if available. Note that though theoretically MMD2 is obtained by squaring MMD, the estimator for MMD2 is not obtained by squaring the MMD estimator (elaborated in App. B), so they give different results. Note that DAVINZ also includes the MMD as a specific implementation choice, linearly combined with a neural tangent kernel (NTK)-based score. However, their theoretical results are specific to NTK and not MMD, while our result (e.g., Theorem 1) is MMD-specific.

Our implementation of MMD, including the radial basis function kernel, follows [42]. To implement our proposed uniform mixture PUsubscript𝑃UP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in cases where Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s have different sizes, we do the following: denote the minimum dataset size by mmin≔mini⁡|Di|≔subscript𝑚minsubscript𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖m_{\text{min}}\coloneqq\min_{i}|D_{i}|italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |. Then for each Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, uniformly randomly sample a subset Di,sub⊆Disubscript𝐷𝑖subsubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i,\text{sub}}\subseteq D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , sub end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of size mminsubscript𝑚minm_{\text{min}}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and use the union DU≔∪iDi,sub≔subscript𝐷Usubscript𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖subD_{\text{U}}\coloneqq\cup_{i}D_{i,\text{sub}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , sub end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Datasets. We consider both classification (Cla.) and regression (Reg.) since some baselines (i.e., CS, LAVA) are specific to classification while some (i.e., IG, VV) are specific to regression. Our method is applicable to both. CaliH (resp. KingH) is a housing prices dataset in California [35] (resp. in Kings county [28]). Census15 (resp. Census17) is a personal income prediction dataset from the 2015 (resp. 2017) US census. [48]. Credit7 [49] and Credit31 [3] are two credit card fraud detection datasets. TON [47] and UGR16 [45] are two network intrusion detection datasets.

Many of our evaluations are conducted under a Huber model, which requires matched supports of P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Q𝑄Qitalic_Q, such as MNIST, EMNIST and FaMNIST, all in ℝ32×32superscriptℝ3232\mathbb{R}^{32\times 32}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 32 × 32 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, and Census15 and Census17. Other datasets require additional pre-processing: CaliH and KingH are standardized and pre-processed separately to be in ℝ10superscriptℝ10\mathbb{R}^{10}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Additional pre-processing details in App. D. Subsequently, each Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows a Huber: Pi=(1−εi)⁢P∗+εi⁢Qsubscript𝑃𝑖1subscript𝜀𝑖superscript𝑃subscript𝜀𝑖𝑄P_{i}=(1-\varepsilon_{i})P^{*}+\varepsilon_{i}Qitalic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q (i.e., ∀i,Qi=Qfor-all𝑖subscript𝑄𝑖𝑄\forall i,Q_{i}=Q∀ italic_i , italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Q). We also run experiments on non-Huber settings in App. D, where our method remains effective.

ML model 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M}bold_M. For model-specific baselines such as DAVINZ and CS, in Sec. 5.2, we adopt a 2222-layer convolutional neural network (CNN) for MNIST, EMNIST, FaMNIST; ResNet-18 [29] for CIFAR10 and CIFAR100; logistic regression (LogReg) for Credit7 and Credit31, and TON and UGR16; linear regression (LR) for CaliH and KingH, and Census15 and Census17. Details are in App. D.

5.1 Sample Efficiency via Empirical Convergence

Our goal is to find a sample-efficient policy that correctly compares Υ⁢(P)Υ𝑃\Upsilon(P)roman_Υ ( italic_P ) vs. Υ⁢(P′)Υsuperscript𝑃′\Upsilon(P^{\prime})roman_Υ ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) by comparing ν⁢(D)𝜈𝐷\nu(D)italic_ν ( italic_D ) vs. ν⁢(D′)𝜈superscript𝐷′\nu(D^{\prime})italic_ν ( italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), even if the sizes of D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime}italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are small. In practice, there is no direct access to P,P′𝑃superscript𝑃′P,P^{\prime}italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT but only D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime}italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; the sizes of D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime}italic_D , italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT may not be very large. Here, we compare {ν⁢(Di)}i∈Nsubscript𝜈subscript𝐷𝑖𝑖𝑁\{\nu(D_{i})\}_{i\in N}{ italic_ν ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to {Υ⁢(Pi)}i∈NsubscriptΥsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑖𝑁\{\Upsilon(P_{i})\}_{i\in N}{ roman_Υ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as we vary dataset size misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Fig. 1 (and Figs. 2, 5, 4 and 3 in App. D) demonstrate that our MMD-based method is overall (one of) the most sample-efficient for different evaluation criteria and datasets, validating the theoretical results (Table 1) that MMD is more sample-efficient than WD.

5.2 Ranking Data Distributions

Motivated by the use-case of a buyer identifying the best data vendor(s), we measure our ability to rank n𝑛nitalic_n distributions based on the values of sample datasets.

Setting. For a valuation metric ν𝜈\nuitalic_ν (e.g., Eq. 1), denote the values of datasets from all vendors as 𝝂≔{ν⁢(Di)}i∈N≔𝝂subscript𝜈subscript𝐷𝑖𝑖𝑁\boldsymbol{\nu}\coloneqq\{\nu(D_{i})\}_{i\in N}bold_italic_ν ≔ { italic_ν ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To compare against different baselines (i.e., other definitions of ν𝜈\nuitalic_ν), we define the following common ground truth, the expected test performance ζi≔𝔼Di∼Pi⁢[Perf⁢(𝐌⁢(Di);Dtest)]≔subscript𝜁𝑖subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖delimited-[]Perf𝐌subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝐷test\zeta_{i}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{D_{i}\sim P_{i}}[\text{Perf}(\mathbf{M}(D_{i});D% _{\text{test}})]italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ Perf ( bold_M ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ; italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] of an ML model 𝐌⁢(Di)𝐌subscript𝐷𝑖\mathbf{M}(D_{i})bold_M ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) trained on Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, over a fixed test set Dtestsubscript𝐷testD_{\text{test}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where the expectation is over the randomness of Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let 𝜻≔{ζi}i∈N≔𝜻subscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑖𝑁\boldsymbol{\zeta}\coloneqq\{\zeta_{i}\}_{i\in N}bold_italic_ζ ≔ { italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The ML model 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M}bold_M is specified previously and the test set Dtestsubscript𝐷testD_{\text{test}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is from the respective P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and not seen by any data vendor. Note that Dtestsubscript𝐷testD_{\text{test}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT test end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is used to obtain ζisubscript𝜁𝑖\zeta_{i}italic_ζ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for comparison purposes, and it is not to be confused with Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is required by some baselines as part of their methods.

Utilizing labels. We also extend our method to explicitly consider the label information via the conditional distributions of labels given features (i.e., PY|Xsubscript𝑃conditional𝑌𝑋P_{Y|X}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y | italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), denoted as Ours cond. Other baselines such as LAVA and CS already explicitly use label information. Specifically, for Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT containing paired features and labels, we fit a learner 𝐌⁢(Di)𝐌subscript𝐷𝑖\mathbf{M}(D_{i})bold_M ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and use its predictions on Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (thus we require Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) as an empirical representation of the PY|Xsubscript𝑃conditional𝑌𝑋P_{Y|X}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y | italic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and compute the MMD between the conditional distributions (more implementation details in App. D). Unlike our original method (i.e., Ours), this variant differs in exploiting the feature-label pairs in Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We relax the assumption Dval∼P∗similar-tosubscript𝐷valsuperscript𝑃D_{\text{val}}\sim P^{*}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by replacing Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with DUsubscript𝐷UD_{\text{U}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, namely for the baselines needing an explicit reference, we use DUsubscript𝐷UD_{\text{U}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The resulting data values are denoted as 𝝂^bold-^𝝂\boldsymbol{\hat{\nu}}overbold_^ start_ARG bold_italic_ν end_ARG (the data values based on Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are denoted as 𝝂𝝂\boldsymbol{\nu}bold_italic_ν).

Evaluation metric. Here ν𝜈\nuitalic_ν is effective if it identifies the most valuable sampling distribution, or more generally, if 𝝂𝝂\boldsymbol{\nu}bold_italic_ν preserves the ranking of 𝜻𝜻\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_ζ. In other words, the ranking of the data vendors’ sampling distributions {Pi}i∈Nsubscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑖𝑁\{P_{i}\}_{i\in N}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is correctly identified by the values of their datasets {Di}i∈Nsubscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑖𝑁\{D_{i}\}_{i\in N}{ italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, quantified via the Pearson correlation coefficient: ρ⁢(𝝂,𝜻)𝜌𝝂𝜻\rho(\boldsymbol{\nu},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_ρ ( bold_italic_ν , bold_italic_ζ ) (higher is better). Note that we compare the rankings of different baselines instead of the actual data values which can be on different scales.

Results. We report the average and standard error over 5555 independent random trials, on CIFAR10/CIFAR100, TON/UGR16, CaliH/KingH and Census15/Census17 in Tables 2 and 3 respectively, and defer the others to App. D. Note that when Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unavailable (i.e., right columns), Ours cond. is not applicable because the label-feature pair information is not well-defined under the Huber model (e.g., for P∗=superscript𝑃absentP^{*}=italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = CIFAR10 vs. Q=𝑄absentQ=italic_Q = CIFAR100, the label of a CIFAR100 image is not well-defined for a model trained for CIFAR10). The Perf⁢(⋅)Perf⋅\text{Perf}(\cdot)Perf ( ⋅ ) for 𝜻𝜻\boldsymbol{\zeta}bold_italic_ζ for classification (resp. regression) is accuracy (resp. coefficient of determination (COD)), so higher is better.

For classification, Table 2 shows that our method performs well when Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is available (e.g., Ours cond. is the highest for CIFAR10 vs. CIFAR100 under ρ⁢(𝝂,𝜻)𝜌𝝂𝜻\rho(\boldsymbol{\nu},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_ρ ( bold_italic_ν , bold_italic_ζ )) and also when Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unavailable (e.g., Ours as highest for CIFAR10 vs. CIFAR100 under ρ⁢(𝝂^,𝜻)𝜌bold-^𝝂𝜻\rho(\boldsymbol{\hat{\nu}},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_ρ ( overbold_^ start_ARG bold_italic_ν end_ARG , bold_italic_ζ )). MMD2 performs comparably to Ours, which is expected since in theory their values differ only by a square and the evaluation mainly focuses on the rank, instead of the absolute values. We also note that CS, by exploiting the label information in classification, performs competitively with Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but performs sub-optimally without Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is because the label information in Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is no longer available in Dωsubscript𝐷𝜔D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (due to Dωsubscript𝐷𝜔D_{\omega}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being Huber). LAVA and DAVINZ, both exploiting the gradients of the ML model, do not perform well. The reason could be that under the Huber model, the gradients are not as informative about the values of the data. Intuitively, while the gradient of (the loss of) a data point on an ML model can be informative about the value of this data point, this reasoning is not applicable here, because the data point may not be from the same true distribution P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: The value of a gradient obtained on a CIFAR100 image to an ML model intended for CIFAR10 may not be informative about the value of this CIFAR100 image. We highlight that neither of LAVA and DAVINZ was originally proposed for such cases (i.e., the Huber model).

For regression, Table 3 shows that Ours and MMD2 continue to perform well while baselines (i.e., IG and VV) that completely remove the reference perform poorly, as they cannot account for the statistical heterogeneity without a reference. Notably, DAVINZ performs competitively for when Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is available, due to its implementation utilizing a linear combination of an NTK-based score (i.e., gradient information) and MMD (similar to Ours), via an auto-tuned weight between the two. We find that for classification, the NTK-based score is dominant while for regression (and available Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) the MMD is dominant. This could be because the models are more complex for the classification tasks (e.g., ResNet-18) as compared to linear regression models for regression, so the obtained gradients are more significant (i.e., higher numerical NTK-based scores). Thus, for regression, DAVINZ produces values similar to Ours, hence the similar performance. We highlight that DAVINZ focuses on the use of NTK w.r.t. a given reference, while our method focuses on MMD without such a reference, as evidenced by Ours outperforming DAVINZ without Dvalsubscript𝐷valD_{\text{val}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT val end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., the columns under ρ⁢(𝝂^,𝜻)𝜌bold-^𝝂𝜻\rho(\boldsymbol{\hat{\nu}},\boldsymbol{\zeta})italic_ρ ( overbold_^ start_ARG bold_italic_ν end_ARG , bold_italic_ζ ) in Table 3).

6 Discussion

Under a Huber model of vendor heterogeneity, we propose an MMD-based data distribution valuation and derive theoretically-justified policies for comparing distributions from their respective samples. To address the lack of access to the true reference distribution, we use a convex mixture of the vendors’ distributions as the reference, and derive a corresponding error guarantee and comparison policy. Then, we specifically select the uniform mixture as a game-theoretic choice when no prior knowledge about the vendors is assumed. Empirical results demonstrate that our method performs well in efficiently identifying the most valuable data distribution. While our theoretical results are limited to the Huber model, MMD is observed to be effective under two non-Huber settings (Sec. D.3.4). Extending the theory to more general heterogeneity models is an interesting direction for future study.

Appendix A Proofs and Derivations

A.1 Equivalent Definitions of MMD

Definition 1 follows [26] to use the function class ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F. In our derivation and implementations, we adopt an equivalent but more convenient form utilizing the kernel and mean embedding [26, Section 2.2]. Definition 1 is more difficult to use with because of the supsupremum\suproman_sup operation. Specifically, recall that ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F is a class of functions in the unit ball of reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS) ℋℋ\mathcal{H}caligraphic_H which is associated with the kernel k𝑘kitalic_k, then the following equivalence holds [26, Lemma 6]:

d⁢(P,P′;ℱ)={𝔼X,X′∼P⁢[k⁢(X,X′)]−2⁢𝔼X∼P,Y∼P′⁢[k⁢(X,Y)]+𝔼Y,Y′∼P′⁢[k⁢(Y,Y′)]}1/2.𝑑𝑃superscript𝑃′ℱsuperscriptsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑋superscript𝑋′𝑃delimited-[]𝑘𝑋superscript𝑋′2subscript𝔼formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑋𝑃similar-to𝑌superscript𝑃′delimited-[]𝑘𝑋𝑌subscript𝔼similar-to𝑌superscript𝑌′superscript𝑃′delimited-[]𝑘𝑌superscript𝑌′12d(P,P^{\prime};\mathcal{F})=\left\{\mathbb{E}_{X,X^{\prime}\sim P}[k(X,X^{% \prime})]-2\mathbb{E}_{X\sim P,Y\sim P^{\prime}}[k(X,Y)]+\mathbb{E}_{Y,Y^{% \prime}\sim P^{\prime}}[k(Y,Y^{\prime})]\right\}^{1/2}\ .italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; caligraphic_F ) = { blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X , italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k ( italic_X , italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] - 2 blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X ∼ italic_P , italic_Y ∼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k ( italic_X , italic_Y ) ] + blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_k ( italic_Y , italic_Y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . The definition of MMD that is used in our derivation and implementation is the right hand side above. This definition is more convenient because it no longer has the unwieldy supsupremum\suproman_sup operation and is interpretable (i.e., resembling the square root of an expanded quadratic expression).

We note that throughout the paper, the class ℱℱ\mathcal{F}caligraphic_F of functions, its corresponding RKHS ℋℋ\mathcal{H}caligraphic_H and the associated kernel k𝑘kitalic_k are all kept constant, so their notational dependence is omitted where clear for brevity.

A.4.2 Results and Discussion for the Uniform Mixture PUsubscript𝑃UP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

As we do not make any assumptions about the prior knowledge of the vendors (e.g., some vendor i𝑖iitalic_i is more reputable), we adopt a perspective that minimizes the worst-case (i.e., maximum) error over selecting the vendor’s distribution as the reference. In other words, we (represented below as the row player) want to pick a vendor, and use the corresponding distribution as the reference to value other distributions. Hence, if we pick a “good” vendor (i.e., whose distribution is close to P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), it is more desirable (i.e., a higher payoff) since the approximation error (as in 2) is lower. Formally, we construct a finite two-player zero-sum game in which we show that the uniform strategy is worst-case optimal. Hence, we propose to use the uniform mixture PU=1n⁢∑iPisubscript𝑃U1𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖P_{\text{U}}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the vendor’s distributions as the specific choice of reference.

A finite, two-player zero-sum game.

The row player (main player) represents the buyer (the one performing valuation) and the column player (hypothetical adversary) is used to explicitly model the fact that we do not have prior knowledge or assumptions about the vendors’ distributions (except each Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Huber).

Observe that this is a finite, two-player zero-sum game.

3: The uniform strategy is worst-case optimal.

While the values of the entries in ℛℛ\mathcal{R}caligraphic_R are not known explicitly, there are some properties of these values that can be exploited. We provide a constructive proof: formulate the primal and dual linear programs (LPs) for the two-player game as in Eq. 4, show that the uniform strategies lead to equal values for both LPs, and conclude that, by the strong duality, both are optimal.

Proof of 3.

3 implies that the uniform strategy is the worst-case optimal approach when selecting a data vendor at the r𝑟ritalic_r-th position (whose distribution to use as the reference) without any prior knowledge or assumptions about the data vendors (i.e., regardless of how the data vendors are ordered).555By the classic [60, Minmax Theorem], these minmax solutions for both players form a Nash equilibrium.

Difficulties of searching over all convex mixtures ω𝜔\omegaitalic_ω.

Note that the game specified in Eq. 4 has a finite action space N𝑁Nitalic_N for the row player. Essentially, it means that the row player is considering exactly one of the n𝑛nitalic_n data vendors as the reference, though the minmax solution suggests that the row player should adopt a mixed strategy to consider all n𝑛nitalic_n data vendors equally.

A natural extension of the game is for the row player to consider all possible convex mixtures ω∈△⁢(n−1)𝜔△𝑛1\omega\in\triangle(n-1)italic_ω ∈ △ ( italic_n - 1 ):

maxω∈△⁢(n−1)⁡minπ∈Π⁢(N)−d⁢(P∗,Pω,π)subscript𝜔△𝑛1subscript𝜋Π𝑁𝑑superscript𝑃subscript𝑃𝜔𝜋\max_{\omega\in\triangle(n-1)}\min_{\pi\in\Pi(N)}-d(P^{*},P_{\omega,\pi})roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω ∈ △ ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π ∈ roman_Π ( italic_N ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω , italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (8)

where Pω,π≔∑r=1nPπ⁢[r]⁢ωr,≔subscript𝑃𝜔𝜋superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑛subscript𝑃𝜋delimited-[]𝑟subscript𝜔𝑟P_{\omega,\pi}\coloneqq\sum_{r=1}^{n}P_{\pi[r]}\omega_{r}\ ,italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω , italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π [ italic_r ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , is a mixture specified by ω𝜔\omegaitalic_ω following the permutation π,𝜋\pi\ ,italic_π , and Π⁢(n)Π𝑛\Pi(n)roman_Π ( italic_n ) denotes the set of all possible permutations of {1,2,…,n}.12…𝑛\{1,2,\ldots,n\}\ .{ 1 , 2 , … , italic_n } .

From a theoretical perspective (i.e., to understand and analyze the optimal solution, if one exists, to Eq. 8), there are some difficulties because Eq. 8 is an infinite game (because of the action space of the row player). In particular, infinite games (or semi-finite games where one player has a finite action space) are significantly harder to analyze the optimality or even existence of the (optimal) solution. In general, it is not guaranteed that the optimal solution(s) exist for one or both of the players [61], and in cases where the optimal solutions exist, there may be a so-called duality gap [21]: The minimax theorem for the finite game implies that the optimal solutions for both players will give values that coincide (i.e., the optimal for row player is the negated optimal for the column player), but the duality gap means that in the infinite regime, the optimal solutions may not give values that coincide, making it harder to even verify if a pair of solutions is optimal (since the values may not coincide even if they are indeed optimal).

Moreover, the MMD d𝑑ditalic_d in Eq. 8 introduces an additional difficulty since it is not guaranteed to be convex in the mixture of the models: for some λ∈[0,1],P1,P2𝜆01subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2\lambda\in[0,1],P_{1},P_{2}italic_λ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the convex combination of λ⁢d⁢(P∗,P1)+(1−λ)⁢d⁢(P∗,P2)𝜆𝑑superscript𝑃subscript𝑃11𝜆𝑑superscript𝑃subscript𝑃2\lambda d(P^{*},P_{1})+(1-\lambda)d(P^{*},P_{2})italic_λ italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ( 1 - italic_λ ) italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is not necessarily smaller than or equal to d⁢(P∗,λ⁢P1+(1−λ)⁢P2)𝑑superscript𝑃𝜆subscript𝑃11𝜆subscript𝑃2d(P^{*},\lambda P_{1}+(1-\lambda)P_{2})italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_λ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_λ ) italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In other words, there are cases where either direction of the inequality is true. The implication is that, when searching or optimizing over ω∈△⁢(n−1)𝜔△𝑛1\omega\in\triangle(n-1)italic_ω ∈ △ ( italic_n - 1 ) via methods that try to “move” a current solution by a small amount to arrive at a new solution (or towards the optimum), it is more difficult to do so, since moving the current solution might increase or decrease the value (and it is not known a priori which).

A.4.3 Additional Discussion on Approximation Error

The result on the approximation error (i.e., 2) can be useful in designing alternative approaches of finding a reference, and also in considering additional desiderata (e.g., incentive compatibility [5] and truthfulness [14]).

Precisely, for any Prefsubscript𝑃refP_{\text{ref}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (e.g., Pωsubscript𝑃𝜔P_{\omega}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or PUsubscript𝑃UP_{\text{U}}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), if it is boundedly close to P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the MMD sense, then a bounded approximation error is available (by the triangle inequality of MMD):

d⁢(Pref,P∗)≤εref⟹∀P,|Υ⁢(P)−Υ~ref⁢(P)|≤εrefformulae-sequence𝑑subscript𝑃refsuperscript𝑃subscript𝜀reffor-all𝑃Υ𝑃subscript~Υref𝑃subscript𝜀refd(P_{\text{ref}},P^{*})\leq\varepsilon_{\text{ref}}\implies\forall P,|\Upsilon% (P)-\tilde{\Upsilon}_{\text{ref}}(P)|\leq\varepsilon_{\text{ref}}italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟹ ∀ italic_P , | roman_Υ ( italic_P ) - over~ start_ARG roman_Υ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P ) | ≤ italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (9)

where Υ~ref⁢(P)≔−d⁢(P,Pref)≔subscript~Υref𝑃𝑑𝑃subscript𝑃ref\tilde{\Upsilon}_{\text{ref}}(P)\coloneqq-d(P,P_{\text{ref}})over~ start_ARG roman_Υ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_P ) ≔ - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). We highlight that this precise formalization and the subsequent discussion have not been presented in related existing works (e.g., [1, 14, 59, 65]), and that this discussion is enabled by the analytic properties of Huber and MMD.

A possible optimization approach for finding a reference and its difficulties.

Intuitively, a smaller approximation error is more desirable (and later we will discuss a specific such desideratum), so naturally we want to minimize it. The following objective is such an example, to be optimized/minimized over all possible convex mixtures of the data vendors’ distributions:

minω∈△⁢(n−1)⁢supP|−d⁢(P,P∗)−(−d⁢(P,Pω))|subscript𝜔△𝑛1subscriptsupremum𝑃𝑑𝑃superscript𝑃𝑑𝑃subscript𝑃𝜔\min_{\omega\in\triangle(n-1)}\sup_{P}|-d(P,P^{*})-(-d(P,P_{\omega}))|roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω ∈ △ ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - ( - italic_d ( italic_P , italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) | (10)

where Pω≔∑iωi⁢Pi≔subscript𝑃𝜔subscript𝑖subscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖P_{\omega}\coloneqq\sum_{i}\omega_{i}P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a convex mixture of the data vendors’ distributions as in 1. The triangle inequality of MMD enables a simplification of Eq. 10 to the minimization of an upper bound (of the original objective) instead:

minω∈△⁢(n−1)⁡d⁢(Pω,P∗).subscript𝜔△𝑛1𝑑subscript𝑃𝜔superscript𝑃\min_{\omega\in\triangle(n-1)}d(P_{\omega},P^{*})\ .roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω ∈ △ ( italic_n - 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

From an implementation or practical perspective, this objective, unfortunately, presents a major practical difficulty in that P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not available (which is the reason for obtaining a reference in the first place). Hence, additional assumptions are required to make this objective tractable (e.g., a validation dataset from P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is available [24, 39, 62], each Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is assumed to be somewhat “close” to P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [1, 14] or the union or some combination of {Pi}i∈Nsubscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑖𝑁\{P_{i}\}_{i\in N}{ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [59, 65]).

We highlight that the assumption P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is available is indeed a key challenge that we aim to address (by relaxing this assumption) because in practice P∗superscript𝑃P^{*}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not available. Hence, exploring a suitable form of the assumption (in the sense that it is practically feasible and also enables a tractable optimization of Eq. 10) presents an interesting future direction.

Additional desiderata.

We make precise the intuition that a smaller approximation error is more desirable by connecting the approximation error to the so-called incentive compatibility (IC), frequently used in (truthful) mechanism designs [5, 6, 8, 14]).

Definition 2 (γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-incentive compatibility).

The valuation function ΥΥ\Upsilonroman_Υ is γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ-incentive compatible, for some γ≥0𝛾0\gamma\geq 0italic_γ ≥ 0, if
